title: How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 will have been reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the United Kingdom as of 1 February 2021?
preds: The lockdown measures are working better than I anticipated - glad to be wrong.

WHO data and decreasing trend line over remaining days now makes this an empirical certainty. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/united-kingdom?country=~GBR
https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb

I miscalculated how much of an effect the lockdowns in the UK would immediately have on the rates of infection. It really reduced the numbers from day-to-day and week-to-week. Adjusting my initial view of the numbers from 4 to 4.5M. to 3.5 to 4M. Good for them, hopefully the trend continues. Previous estimate text: Most recent weekly case count in the UK was 343,000 which was 36% more than the week before. With the new lockdowns going into effect in the UK this week I expect the number of cases per week will begin to decrease. The current case count is 2,654,783 as of 1/5/2021, so even assuming a weekly case count of 300,000 cases it wouldn't break 4,000,000. There is the possibility that cases would continue to rise this week as people who were exposed last week become symptomatic, so there is the potential to break 4,000,000 if cases don't dramatically decrease over the coming weeks. I fully expect more than 3,000,000 cases before February 1st, but from there we will have to see how much the lockdown affects the case count.
Trend has been closing on 20k a day, will unlikely be over 4M in 4 days from now (it will take more than a tripling of the number of cases to near it).

Total PCR tests reported for 25 January 2021 is 196,510.
There are only two days after 06 September 2020 (192,892 PCR tests) with a lower number of PCR tests, namely 30 November 2020 (185,276 PCR tests) and 07 December 2020 (181,493 PCR tests). Over the six days period after that the number of cases by date reported
/increased from 2,988 (06 Sep 2020) to 3,497 (12 Sep 2020), +~16% 
/increased from 12,330 (30 Nov 2020) to 17,272 (06 Dec 2020), +~40%
/increased from 14,718 (07 Dec 2020) to 18,447 (13 Dec 2020), +~25%, hitting 21,672 two days earlier on 11 Dec 2020.
On 25 Jan 2020, more than 3 out of 5 tests conducted were " lateral flow device tests that give results in less than an hour, without needing to go to a laboratory", while less than 40% (192,510 tests) of a total of 542,893 tests conducted were PCR tests.
Whoever is the brain behind this sort of "testing strategy" in the middle of a mutant virus crisis - they must be geniuses.
(It seems the next six days promise quite a few surprises...)
https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/testing
It would require an average of about 55,000 cases/day through 2/1/21 to exceed 4 million cases at this point. https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb

Cases continue trending down, leading to an expected 3.8M cases by the end of the month. At this point, it would take a far more aggressive surge in cases than is likely to occur for the total to exceed 4M. I'm maintaining a 1% chance that a data revision pushes the official number higher.

22,195 cases today. It seems the bad weather has closed various testing centres, and will have prevented many individuals accessing tests. Case positivity has stopped dropping, but we are at sufficiently low case numbers now.
I expect a rise over the week as people can finally get to tests, but one back up to the 30,000 mark. One thing the snow will have done is keep people at home so I wouldn't expect a significant rise in cases from any ill-advised socialising over the weekend before 01/02/21

Clearly a shortage of PCR tests (262,111 PCR test; total tesing volume of 412,204 as of 24 January 2021), almost two out of five tests have been a " lateral flow device tests that give results in less than an hour, without needing to go to a laboratory". No wonder positive tests fall accordingly.
The question remains if and when the real PCR test series will be picked up again before 31 January 2021.
Yesterday 3617463, 8 days to go, currently below 40K cases per day. Would need an average of 47900 to leave bin 3. Going all in for bin 3.

Currently on 3,617,463 cases on 24th January. Average daily new cases over the past week is at 37,156. To go over 4,000,000 cases by 1st Feb the average daily new cases would have to be 54,648, a 47% jump on current average daily rates. I don't see that happening while the UK remains in lockdown and cases are trending downwards, barring a change or anomaly  in data reporting. https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb
The recent cases/day average continues to remain below the approx. 46,000/day average that would (now) have to occur to exceed four million by 2/1/21. (https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb)

The UK just reached over 3.5M cases.  With their new lockdown restrictions that went into effect on January 5th, coronavirus cases have steadily decreased.  Given these restrictions and the current rate of about 200K cases per week, cases climbing another 500K in 10 days doesn't seem possible.
https://www.ft.com/content/50b5563a-c025-44ce-a135-2eb13be96c07
3.5m just reached with 10 days to go.  Rates at about 35k will get an additional 375k cases, so consider it very unlikely to get to 4m by Feb 1.

Back up to 40,261 cases for tomorrow.
But, even with the 4 day rise from 33,400 to 40,300, the case positivity has barely moved all week (allowing for noise) after reducing since the start of 2021. It looks like we are entering the slower stages of recovery. Encouraging for the country, but those numbers will put the 01/02/21 total very close to the 4m mark. 
The 2% will be reduced next week if the case numbers drop along with the weekly drop in tests performed over the weekend. There are concerns about cases rising in Northern Ireland, however they are about as isolated as a part of the UK can be, and the total population is small. That rise would have to filter into the Red Wall and/or London by the early/middle of next week to have a significant impact. The new strain is apparently growing in Scotland and Wales too, which is of larger concern. (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-55768033) 
The news that the new variant is associated with higher mortality is sad, but today's press conference (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/uk-55763212, 22/01/21) hasn't changed anything on the case rates.

Further number of cases falling with recent average now less than 40k cases so 3.5-4m very likely now but doesn't take a huge increase to start creeping up to over 4m so still leaving a chance of that but that window is rapidly vanishing.

1/21/21: The most recent 5-day cases/day average is 37,947/day. (1/17/21 thru 1/21/21.) If this average is roughly maintained total cases should come in below 4,000,000 by 2/1/21. 
(..Assuming there are now 11 days left in this question it will take an average of about 45,000 cases per day through 2/1 to exceed the 4 million number.) (https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb)

Today: 3,505,758
Since my last forecast, daily new cases: <40,000 40,000 cases / day=> <4,000,000

Updating forecast upwards for 3.5-4 based on further drop in latest daily figures but I share @greenbankse's concerns about lack of representation in the test figures. Hard to see what will change significantly over the next 10 days though.

For the decline in new daily cases to be reversed, there would need to be a cause and then a week for cases to rise. There have been no such events/causes reported, which would make less than 4 mln very close to certain.

37,892 cases to be reported tomorrow.
I would reduce the 2% but it is 10 days out and I am concerned about a lack of representation. A new report from Imperial College London has raised questions about whether the lockdown is actually doing anything (https://spiral.imperial.ac.uk/bitstream/10044/1/85583/2/REACT1_r8a_final.pdf). Test positivity is going down, but that is likely a function of how the pandemic is spreading among those who gets tests. It is becoming clearer that the pandemic can be split into that for those who can afford to isolate and those who cannot (https://www.theguardian.com/society/2021/jan/16/low-paid-shun-covid-tests-cost-of-self-isolating-too-high). If the pandemic is actually still continuing at early Jan/late Dec levels among those less likely to get tests, then I fear for a jump back up.  Nonetheless, the reported case rates have dropped below 40,000 a day for 5 consecutive days now. Even if the pandemic is still at its peak levels, it is not being seen among those who get test. The current trend is still far more likely to continue than not, especially with the earliest review for the lockdown on the 15th Feb, and discussions about extending to April/beyond appearing in the press (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-55751915).

3466853 reported on WHO dashboard 21/1/21 which will proably not include 21st numbers as not yet released.  Eleven days to go seven day average c42k but coming down with last few days sall <40k.  This puts <4m very likely now.

Numbers continue to fall, if the question includes cases reported to WHO on the 1 Feb then there would need to be 44.5k cases per day to reach 4M. Numbers have been well below that for quite a while now. This question should really state a cut-off time on the 1st Feb as the position at the start and end of the day could make all the difference.

Clear correlation between low number of PCR tests and low number of cases in past few days.
Testing has been increasing in today's report, and is well below capacity, so it may continue to increase until month's end. As positivity rate is and could remain about close to 10%, the daily rate of cases could rise again as well, as the situation in the UK will still not be entirely under control. It'll finally be very close, but I'm willing to make a bet.

7 day average is now down to 42,000. Cases would need to go back above 45,000 a day to top 4,000,000. Clear downward trajectory in cases over the last 2 weeks. 5% contingency for possible data revision.
Data continue to confirm that the UK is on track to finish the month at around 3.9M cumulative cases.  (barring a data revision)

The UK would have to average less than 47k per day over the next 12 days to fall under 4 million. Currently at 43.4k cases and falling. This is looking pretty likely. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~GBR&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
With WHO numbers it´s 43567 per day to stay in bin 3.  7-day moving average at 43256, trend clearly down (worldometers numbers). I´ve been too pessimistic so far...
Cases are trending down since Jan 10, and they would have to average more than 47,000 cases/day to reach 4000000.
Significant drop in case numbers in the last 4 days. Unless it goes back up to 44,428+ cases a day, it will no longer reach 4,000,000, which is great for the UK, but bad for my Brier.

New case numbers are falling to below 40k a day, suggesting the lockdown is having its intended effect. The lockdown will almost certainly not be eased in the next week, suggesting current numbers will either stabilise (around 40k a day, pre Christmas levels) or fall further to around 20k a day (numbers following the second lockdown). In a stabilisation scenario we may just reach slightly over the 4m mark, which is why the suggested 15% likelihood.

The additional factor to add into this mix is the recent set of lockdowns for the UK that has been extended through March.  This lockdown started January 5th and the UK saw an 80K decrease in cases.  This trend is expected to continue given the restrictions that are in place.
https://www.bbc.com/news/explainers-52530518 There are currently 3.4M cases of COVID-19 in the UK. The rates have fluctuated for the last several weeks, peaking at around 420K per week. Since, there are two weeks remaining, 300K new cases per week need to be reported to end up in the 4M-4.5M range. The graphs for COVID-19 are exponential and thus do not function on strict averages. Exponential averages weight the more recent data more. The last three weeks show averages of over 300K new cases in the UK.  Even with that, there would need to be more than 550K cases per week for the next two weeks to have more than 4.5M cases, which seems high given that we are almost three weeks after the New Year. Low End:
to achieve 3.5M - 50K per week with average rates at 370K per week - highly likely Mid-Range:
to achieve 4M - 300K per week with average rates at 370K per week - likely High End:
to achieve 4.5M - 550K per week with average rates of 370K per week - highly unlikely

The most recent 5-day cases average has dropped to about 46,381 per day. With 14 days left in the question maintaining (or increasing) this average would still result in more than 4 million cases total on 2/1/21. (https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb) If a cases/day average of around 43,000 or lower can be maintained for the remaining period, total cases should fall below the four million mark. Considering current vaccination and 'lockdown' measures the current forecast attempts to reflect this likelihood. (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-55710758)

37,535 reported today. 
Risks of revisions due to increased testing pressure remain. Previous examples are 11,000 cases (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-55105307) and 16,000 cases (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-54412581). 
This is likely to be tight under 4,000,000, I'm expecting just under 3.9million at roughly 35,000 daily cases without revisions.

as of 17/1/21 there are 3,395,959 with seven day daily average now down to c50,000 and dropping. 14 days to go ie to include 31/1/21 reported 1/2/21 would give just over 4m. therefore the rate of drop in the daily average is now key. Actual number on 17/1 was 38k significantly below the seven day average. This suggests <4m now.

Well a lot has changed in a week! Now looking likely that sub 4 million will be the outcome. I think my previous prediction gave too much likelihood to over 4 million for this forecast because on the current 7 day average it would still breach 4 million, although of course case numbers should drop below current average.

Today: 3,357,000
Since my last forecast, daily new cases: 41,000 to 55,000 41,000 cases/day=>3,932,000
58,000 cases/day=>4,169,000

38,598 cases today. It has been a sharp decline, one that should be enough to put the number of cases below 4,000,000. I expect the decline to slow, but crucially it should be below 40,000 per day. However the final result is going to be very close.

Adjusting my initial forecast down slightly due to lower rates in the last week. If the current rates holds (daily average since 1/11) there should be about 4.26M cases; ranging from 75% to 110% gives a shade over 4M to 4.372M.

Annoyed at myself for being overly certain on previous forecasts. Now looks like a clear downward trend in all regions. 46,000 cases per day is the rate for 4 million which is roughly what the rate has been at for the last few days. If it goes down at all, we'll go below. If it goes up at all, we'll go above. It looks to me like additional mixing around Christmas undermined the impact of tier 4 and now without Christmas mixing and with national lockdown the R number has gone below 1. I think given ongoing lockdown cases are more likely to continue to drop or level off than rise, but anything could happen.

I feel like I am trying to play an awful game of signal vs noise. The trend seems down.
16 days out and we have a daily cases number below the required number for 4,000,000. Even if that is natural variaton, one would expect the average figure to reduce over the next 16 days.
seven day average slowing towards 50k per day and less. that puts <4m much more likely
Still think the avg won’t be <46k , can’t see how.

The most recent 7-day cases average is about 52,977/day, but the recent 5-day average is lower, at 48,570 cases/day (1/11-1/15/21). 17 days left in the question multiplied by the lower 5-day average = about 825,686 new cases possible by 2/1/21. That would still lead to about 4,085,948 total cases by 2/1. (3,260,262 current cases + 825,686 projected average.) (https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb) Watching if the current lower daily cases trend continues. UK will need to average about 43,500 cases/day (or fewer) for the remaining days to stay below a 2/1/21 total of 4 million, by my reckoning.

Would have to average under 46.3k cases per day to drop below 4 million. Currently averaging 53.1k cases per day and dropping. Remains to be seen if the sudden drop maintains or was a temporary downward spike, and how quickly the downward trend continues. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~GBR&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc

As of the 15th Feb: 3.2m and 47.5k a day. It is likely given the stay at home measures that there will be a drop of announced cases (so do not believe rate of covid cases will increase beyond 47.5k/day) - but will not drop enough to be less than 350k
Another update. The government update seems to have gone up by ~6,000 daily cases in an hour.

48,682 cases reported today. The window is closing on the reduction in cases trend and similar effects have been seen before where a short drop in cases is followed by a contined rise (thanks to @SE_Meyer for spotting that). 
Nonetheless, some form of peak appears to have been met. The next few days will be critical to deciding the outcome (sorry for sounding like a sports commentator). I have reduced the probability of below 4,000,000 to reflect the lack of movement down in cases.
I'm just eyeballing graphs here. Cases will continue to fall, but I don't know by how much. Cumulative cases will continue to rise, but will they top 4 million? Probably not, but maybe

A small change to reflect the persistent rise at 48,000. But I still think numbers should come down.
The 13% represents the odds of a spike appearing for some reason. That spike would originate from behaviour over the next week, so from then the probability of over 4,000,000 can come down. 
There is also a small chance of cases levelling off at around 45,000 per day, however that is unlikely in such a large scale system. Case rates will (most probably) either be falling or rising, even if very slowly.

It seems I was too optimistic with my last forecast, and the covid cases per day are rising again even with Johnson's lockdown restrictions. Also, the new variant is likely outcompeting the original, so a larger proportion of infected will have the more transmissible variant. The vaccine will not have an impact until after the question has closed (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-55612270).

The 1/13 total (as posted on 1/14 is 3,164,055. Assuming 18 days (reports) remaining until the question is final and that the last two days of totals are not complete. Using the rolling average of 56k per day - that is another million plus making the total over 4.1M. Looking at the average recent daily increase (assuming holding steady) would be about 4.4M. I think the rate will be a little lower than that by the time the questions concludes. Ranging (-25% and +10% - assuming restrictions will lower the rate of new cases being reported): range is 4,047,500 - 4,535,000 (rounded). This appears to be the most likely range, pending and positive or negative spikes in reported cases (which is why I went lower than higher on the ranging).
At the current rate, trajectory heading to 4,000,000...rather tricky
Adjusting projected 2/1/21 total downward for now + watching if recent decline in cases continues. https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb

I've been all over the place on this question, but all the indicators for new cases are now pointing in the right direction. The main other consideration I have is the rollout of asymptomatic testing, but this could in theory help bring cases down towards the end of the the month. https://www.gov.uk/government/news/asymptomatic-testing-to-be-rolled-out-across-the-country-starting-this-week
Lockdown means cases have peaked estimate 30000 a day average for next 18 days roughly 600000. Certainly enough to exceed 3.5 mil but not enough to go over 4.

3m exceeded.
18 days to go.  
Bin 3 - need about 27k cases per day
Bin 4 - need about 54k cases per day
Bin 5 - need about 81k cases per day
Current cases about 45k per day.  This gives bin 3.  Lockdown in place for a couple of weeks though (not sure how much people are observing though) which should mean cases tail off a bit making the threshold for bin 4 hard to reach.  Weighing more to bin 3.

This is a battle between the UK’s lockdown efforts and the new, more contagious strain. I’m inclined to give a bit more weight to the lockdown efforts. The count will exceed 4 million if the average daily cases between now and Feb 1 are above 46,441. It’s statistically improbable it will be below 3.5 million or above 4.5 million
Going to be tight around that 4m mark.
Introduction of stricter measures in Scotland, and a third consecutive day under 50,000, this time with less impact of weekend reporting.
Much as cases rose higher than initially projected, cases are now again falling faster than projected.
Rough estimate based on figures today, change over the last 2-3 weeks, and expecting the next 2-3 weeks to be similar as rate of increase decreases.
seven day average still c57k. 3,118,512 reported by WHO as at 12th Jan incl. 19 days to go equals 4.2m.

3.	How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 will have been reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the United Kingdom as of 1 February 2021?
a.	Initial Assessment: As of Jan 12, 2021, there have been 3,188,522 confirmed cases in the UK. The number of new cases per day has been on the downslope since Jan 9, possibly because of Boris Johnson’s lockdown(https://covid19.who.int/table, https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/04/british-prime-boris-johnson-imposes-national-lockdown-for-england-to-combat-new-covid-variant.html ), and is currently at 46,169, down from 68,053 3 days earlier. This is an average decrease of 7,294.6 cases per day. This will likely not keep up, but the lockdown will remain in effect until Feb 1, and police are getting tougher on violators (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/04/british-prime-boris-johnson-imposes-national-lockdown-for-england-to-combat-new-covid-variant.html, https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-health-coronavirus-britain/uk-police-to-get-tougher-on-covid-lockdown-rulebreakers-idUSKBN29H0OL ), so there’s no reason to expect cases/day to increase in that time frame, and they may even decrease to base levels of around 16,000, as they were before New Year’s. This would likely take around 4 days at the current rate of decline, however, assuming the rate slows and flatlines around 40,000 with 20 days left (worst case scenario): 3,188,522 + 20(40,000) = 3,988,522 < 4,000,000 (These numbers are just an approximation) Ok, now best case scenario: 3,188,522 + 40,000 + 33,000 + 26,000 + 19,000 + 16,000(15) = 3,546,522 > 3,500,000 Both worst case and best case scenarios are within the 3,500,000-4,000,000 range. Barring a massive change in downward or upward trend, I see it staying in this range.
Based on current trends and the time remaining, but will update depending on this week's data to see if it is likely to go over 4M.
Adjusting due to drop in the rate of new cases in the UK (https://covid19.who.int/table).
second day of under 50,000 cases. Lockdown seems to be truncating cases.
Most likely is the middle band here

Numbers do now seem to be leveling off at around 60,000. This trend would put us in the middle of the 4-4.5M interval and so is relatively robust to modest changes up and down in the rate. However, the leveling off could just be a blip and the overall figures are an amalgamation of many different trends in different regions and driven by different strains of the virus, so I don't think we can entirely write off some more unpredictable dynamics here, hence not heading beyond 95+% just yet.

today: 3,072,353
the 14 last day: 50,000 to 68,000 cases per day 50,000 cases/day=> 4,000,000 cases
68,000 cases/day=>4,460,000 cases
Looks like we have reached the peak in daily cases with current lockdowns. That means the likelihood of bin 5 has decreased. Need to move some weightage away from bin5 to lower bins.

Hope I'm not making too swift a judgement but cases seem to be peaking now and the 7 day average has never been enough to take it over 4.5 million so revising down. Crowd seems to be very certain on 4-4.5m and current average would have it at that level but it wouldn't take that big a fall (or that big a rise!) to take it out of that window, I'm not so sure yet that this will be the outcome as a result but it is definitely the most likely outcome. If we are at peak number of cases the drop off can usually be quite big and it would only need to drop to late December levels by the end of the week to start making sub 4m possible.

Forecasting 4.250M exactly in the middle of this bin. Strict lockdown, desperate NHS and public aware of risks - figures will start to slowly decline over next few days, then more quickly towards end on month.

Averaging a little under 60,000 cases per day for the past seven days. (Avg. = 59,653 from Jan. 5 through Jan. 11.) (https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb) An average of 60,000 cases/day times 21 days left in the question = apprx. 1,260,000 additional cases possible by 2/1/21. 3,072,253 total reported cases as of 1/11/21 + 1,260,000 possible new cases = about 4,332,000 total cases by 2/1. The 7-day average would need to drop to around 44,000 cases/day over the remaining 21 days to stay below a total of 4,000,000 on 2/1/21. (44,000 X 21 = 924,000)
A slight rise in the below 4,000,000 because a daily recorded cases is below 50,000. I think the peak has been reached and the cases will start dropping soon, but don't want to go further today.
Continuing uptrend until 3rd week of January, then hopefully trend of infections will reduce as the lockdowns start to show effects.

R number & infections dropping in London & the SE Rates going up a bit in Midland / NW 46K reported on Jan 11th is 20% lower than 58K a week earlier. Seems that current lockdown is having an effect, and in some areas the numbers susceptible may be falling with near-saturation 20 days to go, and 3.12m. Quite possible that average will be below 40K/day over that period, so <4m
There are around 50k new cases a day. In 10 days, 500k new cases and in roughly 20 day, 1 million new cases. The trend is downwards with the strict lockdowns in place.

I was off by a day it appears, so as of today, this needs an average of 44,073.9 cases per day to resolve at 4,000,000+, and 69,073.9 cases per day to resolve at 4,500,000+. There are too many cases on average per day for it to be below 4,000,000, and the number to keep it in bin 3 decreases every day. Today it is between 19,073.9 and 44,073.9 to stay in bin 3.

The UK currently has over 3M cases of COVID-19.  Last week alone, cases soared to over 417K new cases reported in that week alone.  Given the exponential trajectory of this disease, the winter months, limited quantities of vaccine, and spikes after the holidays, this upward trend will continue. Conservative Estimate (numbers will remain the same):
3M + (.42M*3 weeks) = 4.26M Increasing Estimate (numbers will increase from where they are):
3M + (.5M*3 weeks) = 4.5M
Any slight increase from where the numbers are, is enough to drive the total over 4.5M.

21 days remaining, to stay under 4,500,000 they would have to average 70.6k cases per day. Currently at about 60k and potentially looks like they could be leveling off. To get below 4,000,000 they would have to average below 46.7k cases per day. This seems pretty unlikely at this point, they could still climb higher, and if they do start dropping usually it's a gradual decline. Putting high confidence in 4 to 4.5 million cases. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~GBR&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc

I am keeping my pessimistic prognosis.  Compared to results from 06/01 we have an increase of 235.413 cases (with per day average of 58.853). This means that by the end of this month (21 days) we would have 1.235.918 new cases, with total 4.253.331. 
250k space is not enough when the trend is upwards and new cases are rising every day. It looks like epidemic in the UK created another spike, similar to the March one.
The Christmas holidays season slowdown was a result of not a break in trend, but lack of data (less testing, travels, off-work time also for NHS).
Based on ZOE Covid-19 study data

Adjusting my calculations in a more pessimistic direction. Started using a 60,000 baseline rather than 50,000 and have made the R>1 and R=1 scenarios more likely. This is based on reviewing some other well thought out forecasts on here and the message from leading scientists that the current lockdown may well not be enough to turn the tide given the new variant.

With 70000/day until Feb 1, 2950000 + 22 x 70000 = 4497000.
If daily infection number will increase further, which is possible due to mutation (here an impressive annimated gif where you can see how it is spreading https://twitter.com/theosanderson/status/1347683706165747714), it will be > 4500k
UK has no control over the case counts right now. The vaccine rollout is having very little impact. My initial enthusiasm about the vaccines is fading and I am being more and more pessimistic.

Flipping again. I think it is going to be close to 4,500,000, but if it doesn't go up soon, it will be hard to get there. As of today, there needs to be at least 46,582.238 cases a day to get over 4,000,000, and 70,391.762 cases per day to get to 4,500,000.
Adjusting again. I think it will still go up
Flipping because of a few slower days than expected.

As of today (9th January) the WHO is reporting there to have been 2,889,423 cases in the UK and 343,784 weekly cases or 49112 daily cases (https://worldhealthorg.shinyapps.io/covid/). The new lockdown and the end of the festive period are likely to reduce the R rate but as the new variant is spreading 50-70% faster and the current lockdown is less stringent than in March, it is far from guaranteed that this will reduce the R rate to under 1. The affect of vaccination is unlikely to have a major impact on cases before the 1st February. For this forecast I consider three scenarios:
• Scenario 1: Lockdown has limited impact and R rate stays above 1 and retains the midpoint of the current growth estimate (3%). The new variant is still responsible for under 50% of infections in many UK regions, it's full impact will not be felt until it has become the dominant variant throughout the UK (which seems somewhat innevitable now). This effect could offset the beneficial impact of lockdown. It's also important to bear in mind that tighter restrictions might be brought in if exponential growth continues. This scenario would lead to 4531063 cases by 1st February.  This is very close to the 4.5 million cut-off and so I assign this scenario 60:40 between the >4.5M interval and the 3.5-4M interval. I rate this scenario as 20% likely. 
• Scenario 2: Lockdown succeeds in keeping cases stable (R=1) and so the case rate stays constant. Between now and 1 Feb this would be expected to add another 1,129,576 cases to the total giving a total of 4,018,999. This scenario only goes above 4 million on the last day so very small deviations could put it into the lower interval. The probability I assign to this strategy will therefore be split 40:60 between the 3.5-4 and 4-4.5 intervals. I give this scenario a 50% likelihood.
• Scenario 3: Lockdown succeeds in getting the R rate under 1. Let's say it gets down to 0.9 with the new variant and Covid generation time is about 5 days would be a decline of roughly 2% per day. This would lead to a total case count of 3783800. I assign this scenario a 30% likelihood. Rationales for each interval
• 3.5-4 million: This interval is possible in scenarios 2 and 3. I assign it likelihood of 50% consisting the likelihood of scenario 3 + 40% of the likelihood of scenario 2.
• 4-4.5 million: Possible for scenarios 1 and 2. I assign it a likelihood of 38% consisting 60% of the likelihood of scenario 2 and 40% of the likelihood of scenarios 1.
• 4.5 million +: Possible with scenario 1. I assign it a likelihood of 12% consisting 40% of the likelihood of scenario 1.
• Less than 3 million: Practically impossible.
• 3-3.5 million: Requires a daily reduction in cases of at least 6% and so an R rate as low as 0.7 which is the lower bound of what it got to during the initial lockdown which was stricter and without the new variant. This seems very unlikely. I take 1% of each of the highest likelihood possibilities so I can allocate 2% to this interval.

The case numbers are settling with 59,937 reported today (09.01.21) whereas there were 57,725 a week ago (02.01.21). Those numbers are high, but would have to be maintained for the UK to hit the 4,000,000 cases. Over 4.5 million seems very unlikely, unless a surge in cases is hidden in the data somewhere.

Cases may have not levelled off yet, but they seem unlikely to reach the heights required to get to 4.5 cases.
I will update the relative probabilities of the bins between 3.5 and 4.5 million. I think the UK will end up close to 4 million, making this difficult.

The evidence that tier 4 (which is roughly equivalent to the national lockdown) has been working to halt the growth in Kent is essentially zero. This gives me no reasons for optimism that the current national lockdown will be sufficient, indeed there are no obvious signs that case growth is particularly slowing. It seems that a lot fewer people decided to get tested on Christmas day and New Year's, and this may have distorted the data to look temporarily as if it was moving in the right direction. Prepare for super-lockdown and a lot more pain before it starts to gets better.  Hospitals in London are about to be overwhelmed, it is now inevitable: https://www.hsj.co.uk/acute-care/exclusive-london-will-be-overwhelmed-by-covid-in-a-fortnight-says-leaked-nhs-england-briefing/7029264.article And they are basically only forecasting based on infections that have already happened... they are still going up. It would be hard to exaggerate the scale of the disaster that is unfolding. Some indication the government is currently preparing to take some of the few remaining options there are:
https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2021/01/08/crackdown-planned-covid-deaths-hit-record-high/ Also look what just happened to cases in Ireland in the last week. I have this feeling that we may have really met our match with this new variant now...

Difficult time to answer this question, with the recent announcement of Army involvement as well as recent new lockdown. The rate of vaccination is currently 47,000 per day, and is likely to increase with 3 vaccines now available to the UK.  The current number stands at 2.9 million, quite close to 3 million. However, only 50-60k confirmed cases are added per day at the current rate - which already seems to be declining, likely due to lockdown and secondarily vaccination rollout. Even with 24 additional days (the number of days until Feb 1st) of 50k cases per day, we would only just reach 3 million. As such, I believe "fewer than 3 million" and "between 3,000,000 and 3,500,000" to be the most likely candidates. To overshoot 3.5 would require a daily addition of 75k per day, which seems highly unlikely given the new lockdown and vaccination rollout.

according to https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/uk/ the UK currently (as of 8 Jan) has reported 2,957,472 cases, and appears to have an average daily increase of approximately 50k cases each day. With 23 days remaining in January that would put the UK on a glide path to about 4.1M cases. The vaccine may lower these numbers, hence 20% going to 3.5-4M.... but I expect the same type of increase that has been seen.

The rise has been circa 1 million and 600,000 in the last two months respectively. Despite the virus moving faster than the vaccine. I don't think it will increase by more than 1.4m in 3 weeks with the new lockdown restrictions and the Xmas/NY social gatherings out of the picture. The vaccine, travel restrictions and poor weather should (we hope) keep people indoors.

Bumping this down a bit just in case my numbers do not pan out, but it looks like there was another increase today with a total of 62,322 cases. This is just short of the 3.096% increase I talked about below, which would have been 62,802 cases.  In order for this to resolve at less than 4,000,000 the average new cases per day would have to be 48,846.28 or less (4,000,000-2,778,843=1,221,157/25=48,846.28). Each day that goes by where the case numbers are over 48,846.28 will cause this number to decrease in order to still not go over 4,000,000. It appears that the case numbers are going up rapidly, and even though measures are put into place to slow this down, it will not start working for a few weeks. It is likely that it will get much worse over the next few weeks, or at a minimum get a bit worse. If case numbers are to go above 4,500,000, the case average would have to go up to 68,846.28 per day as of today (4,500,000-2,778,843=1,721,157/25 days=68,846.28). This seems more likely considering the large increase in cases over the last few days. However, this number will increase each day that goes by where the numbers are not at or over 68,846.28, as it will take more and more cases to make up the difference. For example, if tomorrow there is 62,500 new cases, the new daily average needed to get over 4,500,000 would be 69,110.708 (4,500,000-2,778,843-62,500=1,658,657/24 days=69,110.708) With that being said, this will very likely be in Bin 4 at a minimum, and potentially in Bin 5 by the end of the time period. Taking into account the potential exponential increase of spread due to the virulence of the new strain of COVID in the UK, I believe it is more likely that we will see an increase big enough in the next few weeks to reach the daily average needed to get into Bin 5 than we are to see it stay in Bin 4. The curve has just started going up, and lock down measures are unlikely to have any real effect for at least 2-3 weeks from when they are implemented. Continued increases will be seen during this time frame, followed by a leveling off and then reduction in new cases over a period of time probably equal to a few weeks. The next few days will tell the full story, as it will continue to require more and more daily cases to reach 4,500,000 if there are no further increases in the daily cases seen in the UK. Since 30 December (last 7 days according to the WHO numbers), there has been a daily average increase of 6.217% in case numbers. While this number is likely to go down over the next few days since the first few days had a huge increase, daily increases in the last five days are averaging at 3.096%, which if this holds steady would mean that the average daily cases needed to go over 4,500,000 by 1 February would be reached by the 11th. I am going to bet heavy on the last bin and will update accordingly as the next few days as we begin to see if there are continued increases or not.

As of 1/7/21 it would take an average of about 67,000 new cases per day over the remaining (question) period (25 days) to reach 4,500,000+ total cases. https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb

With the new lockdowns going into effect in the UK this week I expect the number of cases per week will begin to decrease.  The current case count is 2,654,783 as of 1/5/2021, so even assuming a weekly case count of 300,000 cases it wouldn't break 4,000,000. There is the possibility that cases would continue to rise this week as people who were exposed last week become symptomatic, so there is the potential to break 4,000,000 if cases don't dramatically decrease over the coming weeks. I fully expect more than 3,000,000 cases before February 1st, but from there we will have to see how much the lockdown affects the case count.

I may be slightly more hopeful than the crowd here, which is rare.   Following UK’s Nov. 5th lockdown, cases peaked eight days later, and then roughly halved by the end of the month.  Similarly, I suspect that we’ll see cases rise somewhat for the next week, and then drop precipitously, to perhaps ~25k per day by end of the month...playing around rather unscientifically with some different curves along those lines, I think the crowd is in a fairly reasonable spot right now, but I’m slightly more bullish on bin3.

There are currently 2.7 million cases in the UK of COVID-19.  There have been a range of 125,000 to 344,000 cases per week over the last four weeks.   Lower End of Cases
2.7M + (125,000*4 weeks) = 3.2M Middle Range of Cases
2.7M + (223,500*4 weeks) = 3.6M Higher End of Cases
2.7M + (344,000*4 weeks) = 4M Even though the vaccine is being distributed in the UK, only doses for 400,000 individuals have been shipped thus far.  This coupled with the time needed to build immunity, should not significantly impact the UK's trajectory of COVID-19 cases prior to February 1st.   https://www.bbc.com/news/health-55274833#:~:text=The%20UK%20pre%2Dordered%2040,to%20receive%20just%20four%20million.

We have good testing capacity and a widely-spread new variant that's going to be very difficult to prevent accelerating growth for over the next month. Even if the rate was flat from today onwards, we would have 4.1 million cases by February 1st; there's no way the rate is staying flat, though.

The UK is currently at around 2,600,000 cases. To avoid reaching over 3,000,000 cases, the UK's rate would have to drop immediately to below 16,000 a day for the rest of January. This is so unlikely as to be worth discounting almost entirely (as reflected in the current crowd forecast). Based on the numbers provided  by @raciulo if things stay broadly the same, we're looking at 4,000,000 ish cases. If things get worse and the rate of infection increases more, maybe we'll hit 4,500,000, but it seems unlikely that the Government would not intervene if the cases per day started hitting 60,000 - 70,000.  Potential factors that might result in a slow in the spread: Lockdown: There is very much reason to believe that the UK will be locked down soon [1]. Matt Hancock himself has admitted that the Tiers approach hasn't worked [2]. If the UK goes into a full lockdown (including schools), it's hard to see this not slowing down the rate of infection. Because the virus hangs around for a while before showing symptoms, we're on a lag. Those people infected today will show symptoms in about a week's time. Lockdown would not reduce rates the same day. We might start seeing a positive change in a few weeks. The first two weeks of the November lockdown actually reported an increase in rates before a decline (possibly for this reason).  Vaccine: UK has begun rolling out the Oxford vaccine, but this is happening in very small numbers and is targeted at sections of the population that aren't really spreading the virus very much anyway (the elderly and sick). Furthermore, for the vaccine to be effective in an individual, they require 2 doses a month apart. Therefore, even those first vaccinated in December will not be fully vaccinated until this month. I expect it to be a while before we see positive change from the vaccination program. We only have half a million doses available this week. That's not really enough to make a dent.  [1] https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/jan/04/no-10-resists-pressure-to-step-up-england-covid-19-lockdown
[2] https://metro.co.uk/2021/01/04/hancock-admits-tiers-arent-working-as-third-lockdown-looks-more-likely-13842471/
